text: Mount Vernon was the plantation home of George Washington, the first President of the United States. It is located near Alexandria, Virginia. The house was designed by Washington and built of wood in 1757. It is in the neoclassical Georgian architectural style. Mount Vernon is on the banks of the Potomac River. It was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1960. It is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is owned and maintained in trust by The Mount Vernon Ladies' Association. It is open every day of the year. Mount Vernon is on the tentative list of World Heritage Sites in the United States.UNESCO, "United States"; retrieved 2012-7-18. The property was long called Little Hunting Creek Plantation but Lawrence Washington, George's older half-brother, renamed it for Edward Vernon, his commander in the Royal Navy. Laurence died in 1753 and George eventually inherited the estate. ==Gallery== File:MountVernonrear.jpg|Eastern facade facing the Potomac File:MTVernonseenfromtheriver.jpg|House and grounds seen from the Potomac ==Related pages== * List of World Heritage Sites in the United States ==References== == Other websites == * Official website of Mount Vernon * National Historic Landmark: Mount Vernon * National Shrine: Bringing George Washington Back to Life *"Life Portrait of George Washington", broadcast from Mount Vernon Category:George Washington Category:Presidential homes in the United States Category:1757 establishments Category:1750s establishments in Virginia
